data.title: Download - Qatar Tribune
data.text: WEDNESDAY MAY 22, 2013 RAJAB 12, 1434 VOL. 7 NO. 2452 QR 2 First with the news and what’s behind it WEATHER HOT AND HAZY HIGH : 42 0 C LOW : 29 0 C PRAYER TIMING Fajr: 3:17 am Dhuhr: 11:31 am Asr: 2:57 pm Maghrib: 6:16 pm Isha: 7:46 pm www.qatar-tribune.com www.facebook.com/QatarTribune www.twitter.com/Qatar_Tribune DOHA BANK MAY SELL BONDS TO RAISE CAPITAL PG21 CSK THRASH MI TO ENTER FOURTH STRAIGHT IPL FINAL PG29 FLAUNTING THE BABY-BUMP CHILL OUT QUICK READ Qatar needs more flexible exchange rate: QCB DUBAI Qatar and other Gulf states should consider moving to a more flexible exchange rate, to better manage inflation risk in the next decade, Qatar Central Bank Director (Research and Monetary Policy) Khalid al Khater said on Tuesday. “We in the GCC need more than an outdated four-decade old simple policy framework,” Khater said. A more active monetary policy may now be needed as Qatar plans to spend $140 billion on infrastructure, partly to prepare for hosting the 2022 World Cup. (REUTERS) PAGE 21 Rafsanjani, one other barred from Iran polls TEHRAN Iran’s electoral watchdog has barred moderate ex-president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani from standing in a June 14 presidential election, the interior ministry said on Tuesday. Esfandiar Rahim Mashaie, a close but controversial aide to incumbent President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, was also omitted from the list. No explanation was given. Eight candidates won approval to stand – five conservatives, two moderate conservatives and a reformist. (AFP) PAGE 12 Tornado kills 24 in US WASHINGTON US rescue teams scoured a shattered suburb for survivors on Tuesday after a tornado tore through the outskirts of Oklahoma City, causing chaos and leaving dozens dead, including children. State medical examiner’s office spokeswoman Amy Elliott said 24 victims had been confirmed dead. Earlier reports had cited higher tolls, and the number is expected to rise as recovery efforts continue. (AFP) PAGE 19 EMIR WITH SENEGALESE PRESIDENT The Emir His Highness Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifa al Thani with the President of Senegal Macky Sall, in Doha, on Tuesday. HH the Emir held official talks with the Senegalese president. PAGE 2 20,000 to 35,000 workers needed for Rail projects AILYN AGONIA DOHA THE construction of Qatar’s railway projects worth $40 billion – Doha Metro, Passenger Rail, Freight Rail and Light Rail Transit – will require 20,000 to 35,000 workers to complete, said Qatar Railways Company (Rail) Chief Technical Officer Daniel Leckel. He said the company has been coordinating with authorities and ministries for the provision of work visas and securing the accommodation for the workers. Speaking at a seminar at Qatar University on Tuesday, Leckel said that the ambitious initiative is right on schedule. He added that Rail has started awarding construction contracts. Phase 1 of the Doha Metro, with 48 percent of the structure to be built underground, begins this year and will be completed by 2019. Phase 2 of the project is expected to be completed by 2026. While the Light Rail Transit in Lusail has begun and will be completed by 2017, the West Bay Phase of the project will be implemented at a later stage. DETAILED REPORT ON PAGE 3 Qatar roads’ revamp to cost QR80bn SANTHOSH CHANDRAN DOHA QATAR has embarked upon an ambitious project to maintain and upgrade the road network in the country. Ashghal Manager (Local Roads & Drainage Programme) Saoud al Tamimi on Tuesday said that the Public Works Authority will execute the project worth QR80 billion, which will be carried out across the country in the next few years. In 2013 and 2014 alone, 45 road and infrastructure projects will be implemented in the country. During Ashghal’s Local Roads and Drainage Programme the road and drainage network across five regions of the country, including Qatar North, Qatar South, Doha North, Doha South and Doha West, will be targeted. Meanwhile, Ashghal has also announced the launch of a QR1 billion project to develop Rawdat Al Hamam/Bani Hajer area, of Al Rayyan Municipality, as a quality residential area, boasting of all necessary facilities. To be carried out in two phases, the project is expected to be completed by the end of 2014 and will include construction of roads, public parks, schools and other public facilities in Rawdat Al Hamam. Tamimi said, “The project will provide complete infrastructure including a new road network, a sewerage network, traffic signals and street landscaping that will improve the quality of life in Rawdat Al Hamam/Bani Hajer and the neighbouring areas and provide roads that will link the entire area and ultimately connect it with the adjacent Doha road network.” DETAILED REPORT ON PAGE 5
